If you collected 2 gallons and 6 pounds of recycling, how much money did you get?<n><n>Input2:For every 2 pounds of food you save by eating leftovers, you receive $03. Choices:  A: ditch B: shop C: north america D: pet shops E: outdoors<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Reasoning:<n>An example question. There are 3 possible options and a non-option. The instructions say "choices". (The response that says, "the correct answer is C") is wrong because it's not an option.<n><n>### Input<n><n>There are a lot of people on this planet. The air is filling up. Choices:  A. go around the Earth B. stay in one spot C. be like water<n><n>### Response<n><n>B<n><n>### Reference: How not to do it<n><n>1. You don't read the instructions<n>2. You don't think<n>3. You get the answer wrong and think it's correct and post<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Too many people want to carry and keep exotic snakes. The demand is causing them to carry snakes. Choices:  Too many people want to bring snakes.  Choices:  To keep them.  Choices: A: ditch B C: north america  A: ditch north america.<n><n>### Thinking:<n><n>Too much people are driving a single species of snake. This is not the right answer, but it's possible. You can only carry snakes in north america.

Choices:  A: neighborhood B: subdivision C: city D: suburbs E: street<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>I would choose (D)<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>As I live in a big city, I can't find a place in a big city. For the same reason I can't also find a place in a neighbourhood.<n><n>Also, the answer C has a wrong synonym for neighbourhood(suburb and district are used interchangeably here). Neighborhoods are districts so I can get a house in a district as they are the area that are surrounded by houses of same class.<n><n>Lastly I would have put choice (E) suburbs but I couldn't so I chose choice (D) suburbs.<n><n>[suburbs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suburb)<n><n>[city](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/city)<n><n>[neighborhood](https://en.dictionnaire-francais-anglais.com/definitions/neighborhood?query=neighborhood (link is French dictionary))<n><n><n><n>### Input : She found a book at the library. How many pages were there?<n><n>### Response :<n>A. 85<n>B. 55<n>C. 76<n>D. 83<n><n>### Explanaition:<n><n>The book could have no pages or 205 (which could have been found by choosing B for the answer) and the author just wrote 85 to be on the safe side. Because if the answer was not 65 then the question could be ambiguous. I also don't get why the answer key would not want you to answer 83 so I chose (A)<n><n>[library](https://en.wikiquote.org/wiki/Library_Biblioteque)<n><n>[85](#answer-1)<n><n>### Input  <n>Lynnie put 12 candies from her 24 piece pack into her trick-or-treat bag. How many did she leave?<n><n>### Expected Response<n>A. 10<n>B. 12<n>C. 14<n>D. 18<n><n>### Justification<n><n>C. 16 as the answer because she is leaving 16 to herself as she will also consume those after she goes to a haunted house or if

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:When people discover something new while chatting with friends, why are they likely to continue talking? Choices:  A: agreement B: to fill their time C: discomfort D: misunderstanding E: learning about<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>The correct answer is (E) All of the above. When people discover something new while talking, they are likely to continue talking because: <n>* They agree with each other.<n>* It is time to talk more<n>* It makes them feel uncomfortable to end the conversation.<n>* They want to learn the new thing.<n><n><n>### Input You don’t feel comfortable making the presentation because you find it stressful.<n><n>### Response<n><n>The correct answer would be to get someone else to present the information and make the presentation yourself. You can then talk with those who attended instead of giving the presentation. The alternatives such as practicing your presentation are not likely to reduce much of your stress. The reason is you might be more stressed if you practiced because it would remind you of your previous unsuccessful presentation.

Your boss has 2000 messages, 2000 plants, and 2000 tasks for you to finish. You can only do one of these tasks at once. If you do one of these tasks every 12 hours, your boss gives every employee at your job a $10 bonus each day. How much money can you make during a 1000-day year?<n><n>A. $13,648,570<n><n>B. $12,648,350<n><n>C. $12,136,479<n><n>D. $11,648,150<n><n>C<n><n>### Example #2<n><n>Input: You deliver a message each day for the next 20 days. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The person put on lotion, what did they want? Choices:  A: fresh smell B: good credit C: smooth skin D: fresh produce E: headache<n><n>### Response:		The answer is, "good credit".<n><n>### Reference:<n>[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wash,_rinse,_repeat](https://en.wikipedia...._repeat)<n><n>### Input and output format:<n><n>### Input format:<n>Input: For this task, input 1 line from the command prompt in.txt file, for example - <n><n>`#$@0`<n><n>### Output Format:<n>When no input is entered, output - <n><n>For every 12 can you recycle, you get $0.50.<n><n>But for every 5 kg newspapers you recycle, you will earn $1.50<n><n>Input your answer:<n><n>So in this example, if you enter 12 and 5 the output will be -<n><n>You get a total of $0.50 and $1.00 for recycling these items.<n><n>### How to test<n><n>Run the program, it should ask you 1 multiple choice question, then it should be able to output the correct answer.<n><n>If no answer is input, it should ask the user to pick one(1) answer from the 5 choices and output the correct answer. If it is input, it should output the answer that the user input and then calculate the value.<n><n>### Checklist<n><n>- [ ] Input one or more line in the file.<n>- [ ] Validate the input and print error if there is error.<n>- [ ] Print the correct answer.<n>- [ ] If there is no input, ask the user which answer to select and print out the correct answer.<n>

Choices:  A: liquidated B: own resources C: branch out D: commit crime E: game over<n><n>### Response:		The company liquidates its assets and pay off any debts it owes. It's no longer able to sell any more of its goods or pay any bills it is still liable for. Sometimes the courts will appoint a liquidator to the company in hopes that assets won't get stolen.<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Write a response that appropriately answers the request below.<n><n>###  Instruction:How did the company go into bankruptcy? The company took out a loan<n><n>Input:Because the company took out a loan.<n><n>### Request:You can tell that a company is in financial difficulty: When:<n> A. It begins to fall behind on payments<n><n><n>Input:D.<n><n>### Response:-The company has more assets than liabilities.<n><n>-The company was profitable in the past but is not profitable today.<n><n>-The business has enough cash on hand to cover the shortfall.<n><n>-The amount owed to a company is greater than the amount the company has available.<n> -The company went out of business.<n><n>### Input:- When a company is in financial trouble, sometimes it might have to sell off a building, trademark or piece of equipment. If it must let workers go or fire a significant number of its employees, it could possibly go out of business. If the company's managers feel like the company is in immediate danger of financial collapse and being unable to pay off its debts, they could file for bankruptcy to protect themselves and the company from potential litigation from creditors. This would provide them and the company time to get back on its feet and pay off its debts that it owes.<n><n>Input:Write a response that appropriates completes the request below.<n>Input:- The company can’t pay back the interest or the principal. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:An electronics store had things damaged from the rain, where should these things be stored? Choices:  A: large city B: strip mall C: building D: shopping mall E: aquarium<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input A is the only possible response. Choice<n>A and B are the only stores that have any space left open.<n><n>### Input B is the only possible response A, C, and D all have enough room<n><n>### Input C there are many places available A, B, C, and D<n><n>### Input D A, C, and E are possible responses<n><n>### All the choices have possible responses except A, B, and E<n><n>### Input E there are a number of places available to store these electronics.<n><n># Solution:<n><n>### Instructions<n>An electronic store had things damaged by rain, where should these electronics be stored. The store has the following places available to store these items.<n><n><table><n>  <tr><n>    <th>Building A</th><n>    <th colspan="2">1500 sq ft.</th><n>  </tr><n>  <tr ><n>    <td>500 ft</td><n>    <td>1000/2</td><n>    </tr><n></table><n><n><table>	<n>	<tr><n>		<th>Building B</th><n>		<td colspan="2">3000 sq ft.</td><n>	</tr><n>	<tr> <n>		<td>2000 ft</td><td>3000/2=1500/2=500</td><n>	</td><n>	<tr></table><n><n><b>Input A. Store all of these electronics in building A.</b><n><n><b><i>There are 1500 square feet of extra space in building A. However, the store already uses one-third, leaving a small amount of extra space.</i></b><n><n><table class="table table-bordered table-dark text-center" style="font-family:Cambria;font-size:13px"><n><tr><n>  <th class="colhead">Building</th><n>  <th>Sqf.</th><n>  <b>Total</b><n></tr><n><tr><n><td>Building A</td><n><td>850

Choices:  A: get hungry B: laughter C: injury D: having fun E: feeling happy<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### What does the code tell the computer to do?<n><n>### Output:How many strawberries were in all?<n><n>### What is a valid program to be run on the computer?<n><n>### Input/Output:<n><n><n>```python<n>n = int(input('How many strawberies were picked'))<n>m = n + input('How many more were picked')<n>b = 7 - n<n>e = n * 2<n>c = n + b<n>d = n/c<n>e = d * e<n>print(22)<n>```<n><n>```python<n>a = 10<n><n>while a >= 10:<n>    if a>0 and a<10:<n>        # do something<n>    elif a>10:<n>        print("Cool! you are not a cheater!")<n>    elif a<10: <n>        print("Good job you didn't pass!")<n>    else:<n>        print("This is really boring..")<n>    a = int(input("How old are you?"))<n>    if a>10: <n>     print("You are a cheater!")  <n>```<n><n>### What happens when someone is playing to aggressivly?<n><n>### How many strawberries are in each jar of jam?<n><n>### 2.What do we mean by the term code?Write your response in the textbox.<n><n>### 3.What is an output device?Write your response inthe textbox.<n><n>## 🔃 How to do that?<n><n>## ✨🤩<n><n>## 𐘎💥<n>

How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The sample needed to be pure, but the lab assistant got it what? Choices:  A: corrupt B: applied C: dirty D: contaminated E: fresh<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Feedback:<n>In order to make a reaction a pure sample of reactants, purified solvent, or both is necessary. If one or more of these components becomes contaminated in some form, the sample's purity is diminished. This decrease in purity results from what is called contamination. A pure sample has the properties outlined in the following statements:<n>* The solvent of a pure sample has been isolated to remove all impurities and dissolved compounds.<n>* Pure reactants are free of any impurities that affect their chemical properties and composition.<n><n>**Reference Link:** [https://www.khanacademy.org/test-prep/mcat/content-chemistry/concept-chemical-reaction-and-purification/a/why-are-reactants-pure](https://www.kahnacademy.org/%2Ftest-prep/m<n>at/content-chemistry /concept-chemical -reaction-and- purification/a/why -are -reactants - p ure)<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question:<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: You have 4 quarters and 2 nickels. How many pennies do you need?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input. You have 5 liters of methylamine and you want to make 3 liters of 70 % formaldehyde. Find the volume of water you would need?<n>Answer:1.41 liters<n><n>### Input You have 3.55 liters of 50% methylamine. What volume do you need to make 1.88 liters of 20% methyl group?<n>Answer:2.77 liters<n><n>## Part 2.<n><n>Part 2 of this activity is similar to part 1. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What business has a tower to transmit signals? Choices:  A: city B: toronto C: radio station D: roger that E: medieval castle<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer:<n><n>### Instructions:Write a program without using recursion or functions. The program is a counting program. If the sum of two values added together is 7 or less, the value is added together. If the sum is greater than 7, the value is subtracted. Continue iterating the program until the sum is equal to 0. Use comments as necessary.<n><n>### Program:<n>Answer:<n><h1>Sum it Up!</h1><n>A program that counts using addition and subtraction until the sum is 0:<n><pre><n># Program: Sum it Up<n># Developer: Anonymous<n><n># Input: An array containing values to be summed.<n># Output: The sum of the array values.<n><n>def sumItUp(arr) : # The sum of the initial array value.<n>    sum = 0<n>    for index, value in arr : # Loop through values in the array and add or subtract as necessary.<n>        i = index<n>        while i < len(arr) :<n>            if sum + arr[i] <= 7 :<n>                sum += arr[value]<n>            else :<n>                sum -= arr[i]<n>            i += 1<n>            </pre><n><p> <button class="btn success" onclick="run('sumItUp')">Demo</button> <button class="close-btn" onclick="toggle()">C</button><n>

Choices:  A: food B: cargo ship C: refrigerator D: closet garage E: port<n><n>### Response:		I would put one B cargo ship in the container A: cargo ship<n><n>The given instruction above is using pseudo code to communicate with a child (which could be the program itself), when that child reaches the correct answer it adds one more to it so the next time the child reaches the program, it will then display "2" which is the number of times the child has been right. In this case a refrigerator is a box (container) and it is also food.

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What do people who are speech therapists do? Choices:  A: make music B: believe in god C: give speeches D: complete sentences E: build houses<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:He had been doing favors for everybody at work, it was frustrating not getting any what for it? Choices:  A: let down B: respect C: illness D: satisfaction E: gratitude<n><n>### Response:		<n>In the past, you will always be there to help your friend, that was a good favor. <n><n>### Explanation:<n>1. he had been doing favors: In past tense,<n>2. for everybody: "for" is an adposition.<n>3. at work: "at" is also an adverb.<n>4. what for: this phrase is not grammatical.<n><n>### Input：Why is there no moon during the day? Choices: A: the moon is too small B: it is not bright enough to shine on us C: sun does not shine at that time of the day. D: because it rises and sets at midnight. E: because the sun is brighter.<n><n>### Response：<n>The sun is too bright, so there is no moon during the day.<n><n>### Explatation:<n>In our solar system, the earth has two biggest bodies: moon and sun. During the day, the sun shines on us, and the moon is very little, so the sun is too bright and it is difficult for the moon to shine on us.<n><n>

How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What did the business require of everyone walking into their store? Choices:  A: wear shoes B: learn C: hope for peace D: have a great day. E: do well<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input<n>When Jane bought 14 apples, she asked the clerk for $5 worth of change. She had $6.36 in her wallet. Why can't she give exactly $6.36 for the apples?<n>Choice: A: No change was given. You can't buy apples and keep the money.B: The change needed didn't equal the price of the apples.C: There were too many apples added to the total.D: All of the above are correct.<n><n>### Response<n>B<n><n><br/><div><p style="page-break-before: always;"><a href="https://www.acmicpc.net/ Problem/H/H285"><img src="/images/static/task_hit.png" style="width: 140px; height: 140;"/>A[&ensp;140)&ensp;<a title="문제를 참고로 진행한다." class="ui-icon ui-icon-info-sign" style="margin-left: 15px;"/> View solution</a></p></div> <n><n><n><n>### Input; <n>How much water was in the pool? Choice: A: There wasn't any more water and it was only half-filled.B: There were 6 ounces of water in it and it was full.C: There are two gallons of water and it is half-filled.D: It was 1.2 gallons and it filled the 2.2-gallon pool up the rest of the way.E: It was one-third and it was only half filled.<n><n>### ANSWER: A <div style="page-break: always;"><img src="/images2/task/H/H290_1.png" width="380" /><img src="/images2s/taskH/h290_2.png" width="245" /></div ><p style="margin: 20px 0; line-height: 1.6em; text-align: center;"><a href="//www.acmicpc_jp.net">한국어 문서 ��

Choices:  A: city B: michigan C: three feet D: subdivision E: three arm span<n><n>### Response:		<n>### For each of the Input statements, create, correct or update the Response.<n><n>### HINTS:<n>The unit for a yard is "three feet"; you may see it written as 3ft or 3' or 3 ft. How do you know? It is spelled out, but not every word has to be spelled out when measuring. It is not a city.

School child  E. Control Children<n><n>**A. parent speak freely** 4 children were injured when they were thrown off a bridge. We can find out if the parents were talking to the children.<n><n>In the car we can speak freely, but it is against the law on the streets. Even if the child is 12 year old, we should not speak so freely. The primary duty of the parents as the child grows is to speak freely.<n><n>- The primary duty of the parent is speaking freely.<n><n>### Response<n>

You put 5 into one group, 3 into the other group, and 5 into the third group. How many students belong in each group?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>Answer: 5:3:5<n><n>### Input<n>You have 2 bottles of juice. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What is the opposite of hosting a crowd? Choices:  A: few people B: pay debts C: individual D: single person E: small group<n><n>### Response:		<n>* Select the response that appropriately complements the question.<n><n><n>### Input-based choices<n>```<n>Examples<n>For example:<n>1: Choices:(1 of type A, x of type B, y of type C )  : "A", "B", "C" or "X"<n>```<n>### Input-output choices<n>```<n>Ex examples:<n>3:  "Examples" in the question above is the Input-based choice, and below is the corresponding Output choice.<n>```<n><n>### Reference<n>[Instructional Design-Problem Based Learning](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/learn/modules/instructional-design-problem-based-learning/9-check/){:target="_blank"}<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What is a place that could have tens of thousands of fiddle? Choices:  A: tennessee B: band practice C: orchestra D: violin case E: music store<n><n>### Response:		 orchestra<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Fiddle can be either a fiddle or a violin (it depends on where you live and when you lived).<n><n>### Input<n>What is a place that has thousands of people and millions of pigeons (in the US)? Choices:  C: city A: the mall B: Central Park D: park C: square<n><n>### Response<n>Central Park<n><n>### Exemplar<n>```<n>1....1.	.........	B. 106<n>1.......0.	.........	A. 0<n>...	0.....1.	......... D. 109<n>.....	1.	.........   C. 9<n>2<n>```<n><n>### Input(example):  The teacher gave 58 students a report to write. She asked each student to contribute 40 pages. At least 30 students made it over the minimum. The teacher was happy with how the students worked on this project as the majority of her graduating class are already high achievers. In 6 other classes, the students contributed to a project by creating 10 posters each, using 10 different sources for the information. How many students from the 7 other classes, were considered high achievers?<n>### Response:<n>It depends on the number of students in each class and the number of total classes. There were 58 students and there were 7 other classes. 10 posters had 10 different sources with each contributing information, so each student contributed information for at least 60 posters, or 600 posters in total. 30 students from one class is greater than 20 students from each class, so at least 30 students contributed 600 postcards.<n>```<n>Input:The teacher gave 58<n>Answer:At least 30<n>```<n>

Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:There are many cubicles in the office, they all have computers for employees to what? Choices:  A: teach B: cost money C: do work D: be productive E: help people<n><n>### Response:		Choice D.<n><n>### Input- Choice A<n><n>### Demination:<n>Input: What is the value of x? <n><n>If x = 3, then add 30 and divide by 2.<n><n>If x = -23, then add -182 and divide by 5.<n><n>If x < 0 and x > 2, add 100 and divide by 5<n><n>If x < -23, add 182 and divide -18.<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Input<n><n>How many digits are missing in the following decimal? <n><n>Choose: 💩💩𒓼  💩𫄂💩 💩<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>- The decimal above contains two digits<n>- The second digit doesn't belong as it is less than 5<n>- The first digit is 2<n>- The third digit is <n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. Matthews picked 20 more than Betty and twice as much as Natalie they using their stawberries to make jam.`<n>     break<n>  default:<n>     myReccycledSavings=`The star had 4 gaseous and 4 rocky planents orbiting it part of the constellation. Choose either A,n B,c, D or E.`<n>     break<n> }<n> // console.log('recycledSavines', myRecycledSavo)<n>  }<n>```<n><n>### Instructions for answering this Question:<n>* Open the task editor and paste the code to the task you have been given<n><n>* Open the Task Explorer and run it!<n>* Answer the question and select what the learner will need to do using a button

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Why might a person take a vacation? Choices:  A: relaxation B: good things in life C: admiration D: own house E: needs money<n><n>### Response:		A person takes vacation for relaxation<n><n>### Input:(a) When a person needs to take a vacation, it is probably because he or she is _________________ and __________________. Choices: A: relaxing B: has bad things C: good things D: working E: needs vacation money F: own house<n><n>### Response:(a)When a person needs to take vacation, it is because he or she is relaxing.<n><n>### Input:'One-third of a dozen' is ____________________. Choices: A. a one-hundredth of a hundred B. a dozen<n><n>### Response:'One-third of the dozen' is a dozen<n><n>## Solution<n>1. In this example we had to divide amount by the number.<n>```<n>$0.50/12=$0.04<n>$1.50/5=0.30<n>144/12=$12<n>```<n>We have to divide 144 by 12 and divide 30 by 5.<n><n>2. In this example we have to find the value of expression.<n>```<n>$4/7=`4`<n>Betty picked 16 stawberries<n>Matthew picked 20 more then Betty<n>So 20 more means 36<n>Matthew picked  36+16=52<n><n>So they Used their strawberries they had 48<n>$4/6=`48`<n><n>```<n><n>3. In this example we found the relation ship between each other in options.<n>```<n><n>```<n>A: relaxation<n>B: has bad things<n>C: good things<n><n>```<n><n><n>## Future<n>[GitHub Repository](https://github.com/shayan128/SolvingRules)

Explain how you know.<n><n>### Input<n><n>What would happen if we added a new item (money) to the set {apple, banana}? Choices: <n><n>1   A: the set got bigger<n>2   B: we'd end up with one item<n>3   C: we're not adding anything to the set<n>4   D: we'd end the set with two items<n><n>### Response<n><n>Explain how your knowledge allows you to choose the correct answer for each choice.<n><n>### Question:<n><n>This scenario describes a situation. Choices:  A: redemption B: isolation C: absolution D: great relief E: feel better<n><n>### Response:		<n>Their is relief to their forgiveness.<n><n><img src="images/pastedimage.png" style="width:1200px; height:693px;"><n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>* Include comments on each line if there are no test cases run<n>* Answer only one of the questions.<n><n>### Code<n><n>Here is a description of the task.<n><n>1. The function contains two parameters. <n>4. Write at least 25 lines of code in the function.<n>	1. The function can have any number of loops or iterations.<n>	2. The program may use any combination of variables of types float, double, int, String, or boolean.<n>  5. The program must do any number of mathematical operations on an assortment of types.<n><n>## Question 1<n>* Write a function that receives the string "Hi," and outputs the letter "s" if the "h" is in the string. <n>* Do not return any code other than the letter.  (If the output is "s," then that is what we want to return.)<n>* The function should have two parameters and return a value in a String.<n><n>## Question2<n>* Write a function which receives a character and returns true if it is an uppercase letter. Return false if otherwise. <n>*/<n><n>/**<n> * @param {char} letter<n> * @returns {boolean} <n>*/<n>function Uppercase(letter) {<n>	   /*<n>	     * The character is uppercase if it is a letter but not if it starts off with a capital letter.<n>	     */<n>   return letter == letter.toUpperCase() || (letter.length == 1 && letter.toLowerCase()).replace(/"/g,'');<n><n>}<n><n><n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What would something be if you do not need it? Choices:  A: satisfied B: unnecessary C: luxury D: sufficient E: extra<n><n>### Response:		<n>A. An item of worth that is unused and unneeded is a luxury. Something you use that has no use is extra. Something that satisfies you is sufficient. Something you use but don't need every day could be considered necessary, but not something you depend on for living.<n><n>### Input How many different combinations could you have between numbers 1-10?<n><n>### Response<n><n>#### 10!/6!7!3!2!<n><n>### Input Write a program to perform addition and multiplication.<n><n>### Response Addition:<n>```<n>		public void addition(int a, int b){<n>		int res=a+b;<n>			System.out.println("The sum of "+a+","+b+ " is "+res);}<n>```<n><n>### Response Multiplication:<n>```<n>	public static void main(String[] args){<n>		int a,b,d;<n>		Scanner s = new Scanner(System.in);<n>		System.out."How many numbers would you like to use?";			<n>		d=s.nextInt();<n>		System.Out.println("How many numbers would you use at a time?");<n>		a=s.nextInt(d);<n>		System(out).println(a);<n>		for (int i=0; i<d; i+=2)<n>	   	{<n>	   		System.Out.println("Enter your "+i+"th number");<n>	   		b=s.nextInt() ;<n>	   		for (int j=0; j<a; j=i(d-a)+2)<n>	   2			d*=2;<n>		d*=b;<n>		System. Choices:  A: music shop B: music store C: jug band D: united states E: among nice people<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A<n><n>### Detailed explanation:<n>The banjo is mostly a musical instrument, but not always as it depends on the place.<n>in Africa, the ukulele came from Caribbean and some people say the banjo is African.<n>In the United States, the banjo is a symbol for the old time, so i think banjo came from the united states<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple Choice Question.<n><n>### Detection:<n><n>What does the pig find in the farm? <n><n>### Solution:<n>The pig found the treasure.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>The pig finds the treasure and the other pig finds nothing.<n><n>### Input<n>In a small village many children walked to school down one long road.  The village baker made his deliveries this morning along this road.  There were 13 red houses, 20 green houses, and 4 purple houses. 5 children were at the house of their parent who rode the bus.  What were the total number of children?<n><n>### Examination: <n>The solution is 33 children.<n><n>### Justification: <n>Because they were 5 children on the bus, and the 13 red houses and the 20 green houses means they counted the houses from left to right, so we counted 13+20, then they counted the 4 purple houses and that's 2+4=6. Then we divided them both and we got 5,5.

She also saw three more apples than Cindy saw. Annie ate 9 of the apples to make applesauce. How many apples can you make using a half recipe?",<n>"Choices:  A. 5 B. 4 C. 3 D. 6 E. 7"]<n>```<n>### Output:<n>```python<n>out = [str(n + " is the correct answer, as it matches choice {0}.".format(i)).lower() for n, i in enumerate(input_lines, start=1)]<n>for answer in out:<n>    print(answer)<n>```

Also, create a method that takes a word and an array of words from the input array as input, and returns a sentence that contains the word and all of the words in the input array. The methods should be called from the `main` method and should be the only method called from this method.<n><n>```java<n>public static void main(String[] args) {<n>    String[] words="jared john doe tennessee barnacle";//string<n>    String[] out=getWordArray(words);<n>    System.out.println(joinWords(out,out[0]));<n>}<n>```<n><n>### Answer:<n>I wrote methods as following.<n>![image](/mynmbr-assets/images/27960a0b6052426e739396e011de239b.png)<n><n><pre><n>public static String[] getWordArray(String[] words) {    <n>       int length =words.length;<n>       String[] w1 = new String[length];<n>       int i=0;<n>       for(; i<length; i++){                       <n>           w1[i] = words[i];<n>       }                                           <n>        return w1;}<n></pre><n><n><pre> <n>public static String joinWords(String[] w1, String w2 ) { //w1 를 input 로 받고                                      이입니다.<n>        String join = "";<n><n>        for(;w2.length() > 0;w2 = w2.substring(0,w2.length()-1)){<n>            if(w1.length() == 0) { //joing is empty<n>                return w2;}                                            <n>            if(w2.equals(w1)){                                <n>                return w2 + join;}<n>            else{<n>                join = w2 + "; " + join;}<n><n>            if(w3.length() == 1 && w1.length() ==0){                                   <n>                return w2+join;}                                                <n>        }<n>        return join;<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:If you're speaking to a lawyer about getting a divorce, what relationship status are you trying to end? Choices:  A: being married B: sisters C: marriage D: two people E: lawyer<n><n>### Response:		Divorce<n><n>### Input : A: Is it okay if I call you at 2 PM? B: No, if it's 2 PM, I'm going to be busy.<n><n>### Response : it's okay <n><n>### Input  : Are you still having issues with the printer?<n><n>### Response  : yes<n><n>### Input   : The next item on the agenda is....<n><n>### Response   : to discuss the budget<n>#### Solution<n><n>### Code 1: <n>```python<n>def first_input(input):<n>    return input<n>def second_input(input):  <n>    return input.index("in")<n><n>def third_input(input,value):<n>    for i in input:<n>        if i==value and index == len(input) -1 :<n>            return index+1<n>        index += 1<n><n>def fourth_input(input, value):<n>    index = second_input(input, "in")<n>    while index <= len(input):<n>        if (input[index]== value):<n>            return index+value<n>        else:<n>            index+=1<n><n>def fifth_input(input,answer):<n>    index = third_input(input,"at")<n>    return index + answer # at is in at the end<n>```<n><n>### Result:<n><n>### 1. A function to receive an incoming call. <n>```python<n>        def input(user):<n>            input="Hello how can i help you? "<n>            return input<n>```<n>### 2.A function to pick any item from the array of arrays<n>```python<n>        test_input("Hello"+user")<n>```<n><n>## 6. Code:<n>```python<n>    if item == input:<n>        print("you are already there")<n><n>    list.append(input)<n>```

");<n>scanf("%s", &name);<n>printf("What is 16 * 139? ");<n>scanf(" %d",&sum);<n>printf("What's the sum? ");<n>scanf "%d", &a;<n>printf("%d", a+sum);<n>}<n><n>```<n>## My code<n>```c<n>#define MAXN 251<n>#define MAXS 51<n>#define I 1<n>#define O 0<n><n>char map[MAXN][MAXS];<n>int dp[MAXN][MAXN][MAXS][MAXS];<n><n>// dfs，使用指针<n>void dfs(int i, int j, int x, int y)<n>{<n>	if (dp[i][j][x][y] == -1)<n>	{<n>		dp[i][j] = (i >= 0 )? dp[i][j][1][x][y] : -1;<n><n>		if (i == 0)<n>		{<n>			dp[i + 1][j][x][0] = 1;<n>		}<n><n>		for (; i < max(0, dp[i + 1]); i++)<n>		{<n><n>			if (!map[i][0])<n>			{<n>	<n>				// 判定为i=0<n>				continue;<n>			}<n><n><n>			for (j = 1; j <= x; j++)<n>			{		// 1 <= i / x <= max(0, dpi + 1)<n>				if (y >= 1)<n>	<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:If you've thrown a rod you've done damage to what? Choices:  A: fishing camp B: hardware store C: engine D: your spine E: sporting goods store<n><n>### Response:		<n>Your spine<n>### Explanation:The only rod mentioned in the question was the rod from which the line is attached. The only thing the line could have touched was the spine. The rod itself couldn't have any impacts at all. No other options make sense, and even in a fishing camp there shouldn't be any spine damage when one has thrown a rod.<n><n>### Input <n>A train leaves New York at 11:30pm and arrives in Boston at 6:45am, and a plane leaves Boston at 7:15am and arrives in New York at 12:00pm. How long is the flight from Boston to New York?<n><n>### The train goes from 11:39pm to 7:00am, it’s a 23 hour 29 minute trip, not 29 minutes.<n><n>### A plane flying from Boston to New York travels 2,196 miles. The train travels 300 miles.<n><n>### The actual flight from New York to Boston is only one hour, but the question is ambiguous.<n><n>### When we think of a train, we think of the journey and therefor the trip from Boston to New York cannot be 23 hours 29 minutes. The train’s journey takes far more time than the 23 hours 48 minutes, because of stops and other delays which is why only the 23 hours travels are accounted for.<n><n>### Explanaton:<n>The train travels so much faster than the plane it completely ignores the amount of miles that the plane flies, and instead focuses on the journey.<n><n>### Example:<n>If the plane travels 1100 miles/2,400miles, and it arrives at it's destination in 8 hours, it's journey takes 13 hours.<n><n>An actual flight from Boston to Newyork is 800 miles and takes only an hour.<n><n>### Another example<n><n>If the plane traveles 100 miles/50 miles, 1000 miles and it arives at it's destination, then it's journey takes four hours.<n><n>Another flight from Boston to New york is 700

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where can peanut butter be stored? Choices:  A: container B: supermarket C: pantry D: sandwich E: jar<n><n>### Response:		<n>1 - [Because of it's high viscosity, it is advised to keep the peanut butter in an air tight container, away from direct sunlight.][1] Peanut butter has a very high viscosity to the point where it is liquid at room temperature, it is advised that you don't store your jar of peanut butter at room temperature.<n>2 - [The peanut butter sits between the sandwich and the bread, in a sandwich, making sure that the bread and peanut butter sit on top of each other, so not to squish the sandwich or get sandwich crumbs on your peanut butter, making your peanut buttar taste bitter.][2]<n>3 - [The best places to store food is in the pantry or refrigerator rather than on the counter.][3]<n>4 - [If a peanut butter is exposed to direct sunlight, it will dry out and harden. Make sure not to keep on top of the counter.][4]<n>5 - [Jars of food products have an expiry date, because it can be re-activated whenever you want, with or without a lid.][5]<n>6 - [Keeping peanut butter can help to increase shelf life, without adding preservatives. By putting peanut butter jars in the fridge, the shelf life will increase. But if you freeze it, there will be no shelf life.[6]<n>7 - [Keep it in a dry place.][7]<n><n>### Note:<n>1. https://www.healthline.com/health/food-nutrition/how-long-does-peanut-butter-last#pantry<n>2. https://www.bonappetit.com/story/how-to-make-peanut-sandwiches<n>3. https://www.popsugar.com/food/Pantry-Pantry-Organization-34709159<n>4. https://www.wikihow.com/Store-Peanut-Butter<n>5. https://www.thespruceeats.com/best-peanut-buutter-brands-10070

Choices:  A: overhead compartment B: chair C: hospital D: in shirt E: business meeting<n><n>### Response:		C<n>### Sample Output:<n>A: overhead compartment<n>B: chair<n>C: hospital<n>D: in shirt<n>E: business meeting<n>B: chair<n><n>### Subtask:<n>Design a method called AnswerQuestions() that creates an instance of the class Answer<n>- This class should define a question() method.<n>- The method question() should accept an array of integer strings as its only argument, then should return a single string as its response. The order of the numbers in the integer string array passed to question() defines the sequence of operations that answer the question, where the zero index corresponds to the first operation, the first index corresponds to the second operation, and so on. The operations in question() may not be executed in parallel, and only operations defined in question() should be executed when the question is processed. These operations in question() should not be recursive. The operations in question should be performed as follows:<n>  - If the integer in the first operation in question() is 0, then the inputted array should be reversed.<n>  - If the last operation in question() is not 0, then the element in the inputted array at the last index of question() (excluding the last element) should be reversed, and the element at the last index should be removed.<n>  - If question() is called without any integer in its array, then question() should return "N/A"<n><n>This question is from https://codeforces.com/problemset/problem/512/C<n><n>### Demo Inputs<n>![](demo1.png)<n>Input: A 7 9 4 11 -4 (A 7 9 11 6) 3 5 (B 2 5 5 10)<n>![](demo2.png)<n> Input: -23 -9 -56 5 -6 67<n><n>### Demo Outputs<n>![](demo3.png)<n>Response: 2 6<n><n>### Demo Question<n>Input:Where would someone likely hang a clock? Choices: 1. A: on the wall 2. B: on the ceiling<n><n>Response: B<n><n>### Demo Instructions<n><n>##<n><n>![](demo_question.png)<n>### How To Write a Solution<n><n>### Part I<n><n>#include <

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:There's a lot to reproducing, but it begins and end with new life by giving what? Choices:  A: overpopulation B: birth C: presents D: propagation E: fun<n><n>### Response:		Answers should be limited to one complete, grammatical sentences. Write as much as you could write without asking for clarification from me.<n><n>### Reasoning<n><n>### Input<n><n>A 3-by-3 triangle is known as "triangle abc" and is commonly taught in a geometry class.<n>If the sides are called a,b, and c respectively, one can say a triangle is "the set of 3 points a, b, and c.", or "a triangle, denoted as triangle abc, is the set of 3 points {a, b, c}".<n>Another alternative definition of triangle abc:<n><n>A triple of numbers: a, b, c such that, (a ≠ b) (a ≠ b ≠ c).<n>In other words, three numbers a, b, and, where (a, b) is not the same sequence as (, : b and c.<n><n>### Output<n><n>One can write out triangle abc, but usually, one must denote a triangle as "abc" with a subscript.<n>For instance, the triangle shown is triangle abc in the diagram.<n><n>\[a_{1}\] is the (first) lower, right, and outside corner of the triangle, written as a, noting that in this case the triangle is the one with an equilateral triangle;<n><n>\[a_2\] is the (first) upper diagonal line, written as b;<n>\[b_{2}\] is the (second) lower diagonal line, written as c.<n><n>\[\triangle abca\] is the equation for the area of the triangle abc.<n><n>### Clarification<n><n>The triangle must be equilateral and a right triangle, and at its base (or where it is placed) must be at the corner of the original triangle.<n>For instance, triangle ab is not the triangle ab since it is not the right triangle triangle abc and not the equilateral triangle triangle abc. See triangle abc for a definition of triangle abc.<n><n>In the diagram triangle abc, triangle ab is the equilateral one, with the base (triangle abc is triangle ab or triangle abc) at (), it is right, but not equilateral since not all three ( or a) are equal.<n>Another way is to note that triangle abc is triangle acb.<n><n><n>### Con

Choices:  A: at the zoo B: south carolina C: hen house D: louisiana E: arkansas<n><n>### Response:		<n>C  <n><n>### Solution:<n>if person sees a fox, then they must be in a state that has foxes!<n>We know all of the land locked states are the south (no coast line), so this leaves us with Kentucky, Tennessee, Missouri, Arkansas, Mississippi, and Louisiana.<n><n>### Input1: A: a: b: c: d: e: f: g: h:<n><n>### Response1<n><n>### Input2: e1: a1: b1: c1: d1: e2: a2: b2: c2: d2:<n><n>### Output: A: a:<n><n>### Solution2:<n><n>## Description:<n>**Expected Results:** The solution to the given problem.<n><n>## Setup:<n>## Known Inputs:<n>### Argument Unknowns:<n>```<n>### Argument Unkowns:<n>## Solution:<n><n>### Notes:<n><n>### Description:<n>The following section outlines every field that is required for inputting a test response. For example, a response for the question above would need to include the following elements:<n><n>```<n>### Inputs:<n>* 4 values: choices(A B C D) and answer(C).<n>* 3 values: choices(A E F) and answer(E)<n>* 2 values: choices(A A1 A2) and answer(A1)<n>* 3 values(a a1 a2): answers(C1 C2 D E F).<n>```<n><n>## Expected Results:<n><n>* Test responses can be evaluated as to whether they contain the correct combination of inputs.<n><n>## Errors:<n>* If a test response does not contain the correct combination of values, evaluate the resulting incorrect response and exit with an error. In such a case, you must print out the correct combination of inputs that is expected.<n><n>* If a test resposes contains the correct combination of inputs, but the correct answers are not found in the response, evaluate the response and provide the correct answers.<n><n>## Notes:<n><n>## Description<n><n>The following are common problems that are encountered while implementing this testing technique. These common problems are identified by the description prefixed to each note.<n><n>### Description 1<n><n>The solution should be provided as a string representing the solution input.

Choices:  A: necklace B: wall outlet fixture C: tool box D: computer E: motorcycle<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>> 1. A.<n>Chainsaw that has dull or blunt cutting teeth are difficult to work and cause the user to work harder. Chain rings helps to replace or sharpen dull saw chains. This can help chainsaw last longer and more efficient for wood cutting.<n><n>> 2. B.<n>Wall outlet can be fixed quickly by screwing a chain ring.<n><n>>3. D.<n>Changing motor oil is very important for the engine and prolong its life. A motorcycle chain and chainwring is designed to work with high power that engine is produce. Chains and chainring need to be checked for wear or damage. Some models will have a quick-connect style chainring. This means the entire chain ring will disconnect to a single bolt and chain. The chainring can be screwed on over it.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:A person writes a check to a clerk, where does the clerk put them? Choices:  A: cash register B: desk drawer C: pay envelope D: throw away E: box<n><n>### Response:		<n>Checks are typically recorded in the banking application. The check amount is subtracted from your account balance and the bank may charge your account a nominal fee for writing the check. Once processed, the check is forwarded to one of several locations:<n><n>1.  If your account balance is sufficient to cover the check, it will remain in the banking application and wait to be cashed by the customer.<n><n>2.  If your account does not have sufficient funds, the bank may record the check in the customer’s accounting system, send a check to the write, or send the customer a notice of overdraft.<n><n>3.  Payment Processing: In more complex banking applications, checks may be stored and processed via ACH, wires or any other payment system.<n><n>### Input 4: Betty picked 1287 strawberries. Betty and Matthew sold 356 strawberries for $5 each. Matthew also sold 120 strawberries for 3 times the price of Betty’s strawberries. If Betty paid $26.99 for the strawberries and sold the 356 for $1818, but had to pay for the rest, how much money did she have after selling her strawberries? <n><n>### Response 5:<n>Checks may be recorded in your banking application for up to months. When the bank needs funds to clear checks, it can either draw funds from your money market account or from funds on overnight loans from its clients. The funds then go back to the source the money is withdrawn from and you pay the lending institution a fee. These fees vary depending on how the check is processed. The process can be complex and banking application developers are continually enhancing their applications to manage the complexities of this transaction.<n><n>### 6.<n><n>You receive $5,000 at 4%. If it is invested at these different interest rates, how must the principal grow in order to end up with $10,000? Choices: A: $1000 B: $100 C: $100<n><n>Answer: I guess you mean how much will the principal have to grow?<n><n>### Inputs:<n><n>### Response<n><n>We can use a comp

What should you do so you're less likely to get frostbite if you step outside in this temperature?  Choices:  A. Put on sunscreen B. Put on a scarf C. Put on a sweater D. Put on mittens E. Put on a coat<n><n>### Response : E<n><n> - A and B represent incorrect answer choices because sunscreen and a scarf would not help protect against frostbite when the temperature is below freezing. The only item in E that would help protect against frost bite when the temperature is <0 degrees Celsius is a coat.<n><n>### Input A fruit vendor has 120 oranges. She decides to offer 8 oranges to each customer who buys 2 apples. She sells 98 apples in 5 minutes. If a customer brings 3 limes in exchange for a boxful of oranges, how many oranges is it likely the vendor has left? <n>### Response:  A. 24 B. 44 C. 54 D. 64<n>### Justification:<n>- Choice A: If we know the fruit vendor sold 98 apples to customers who only bought 2 apples, it means an additional 4 apples were sold to customers who bought more apples, so 102 total apples were bought. That leaves only 18 oranges remaining.<n>- Choice B: 120 or 12 x 10. If she sells 98, then she still has to sell 12. That accounts for 122 oranges since 102 apples were sold. Since she has no apples left, this is not an option.<n>- Choice C: 120 + 8 x 18. If she sells only 18 apples, then she only has to sell 102 appes so that 24 oranges are left.<n>- Choice D: 120 - 12 ( the total number of apples she sold and the number of apples she has remaining).<n><n>### Input The

However, the Petro-Canadastation was also full of people buying gas, so it took 50 minutes, even if you had been the first in line. If the 16th mile runner cost you 7 dollars, the 15th mile runner cost you14 dollars and the 14th mile runner cost you $5 and the 12th mile runner cost 12 dollars, then how much will the 20th mile runner cost you?<n>4. (Note that your responses may need some modification if you were to implement your methods as programs.)<n><n>Your cousin, James, went apple picking with his friends. When he got home, he found he had no apples left. He shared them evenly among himself and his friends. He had 6 more apples left after he gave them away. How many apples did he start with?<n><n>### Instrution:James had 8 apples so 7 friends to share between. he gave 3 away and the 6 friends left had 6 apples left.<n>### Demonsteration:<n>1. a) The apples James had are halved to each friend. that makes 9+9+5+5=8+7=15 divided by 2=15/2=7.5 apples per friend. b) To add the friend you need to share 8 apples with the rest. the rest is 7 people and each has 7.5 apples. 2+1+1+1+2+1+2+2=7.5+7.5+7+5.5+5+7/7=8<n><n>2. b) He can take it apart to each person he can go with a full box and each one can eat them on one. that makes 9 fruits 9. <n><n> <n><n><n><n><n><n>### Input : A 12-year old boy weighs the same as an adult woman.<n><n>### Input  :  A three month old baby girl weighs the same amount as four 7-year-old boys.<n><n>### Response : 160<n><n>### Instuctions: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>### Demostration:<n>1. E=10 + 50 <n><n>### Instution: <n><n>Input: The distance between a town and a city is the same number as how many kilograms of apples would be used to make a batch of applesauce. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:She'd sooner just spray herself with water than the what she didn't like the smell of? Choices:  A: perfume B: air C: fountain D: swamp E: puddle<n><n>### Response:		<n>```console<n>>>> from dataclasses import dataclass, fields<n>>>> from typing import Optional<n>>>> import time<n>>>><n>>>> class Plant(dataclass):<n>        def __init__(self, name: str, likes: "type", dislikes: "type"):<n>            self.name = name<n>            self.likes = likes<n>            self.dislikes = dislikes<n>        def to_string(self):<n>            return f"\t{'Name':<{str(printable)}'s}\t  {self.likes}  {:><20}{self.dislikes}"<n>        def __repr__(self):<n>            return str(self.to_string())<n>        def __str__(self):<n>            time.sleep(3)  # Sleep to allow user to scroll through console<n>            return self.to_string()<n>        def to_json(self):<n>            """The only method that should be used to convert the dataclass to a dict"""<n>            return {"name": self.name, "likes": self.likes, "dislikes": self.dislikes}<n><n>        class LikesDislikes(dataclass):<n>            def __init__(self):<n>                self.likes = fields(20, gt=1)<n>                self.dislikes= fields(20, lt=1)<n>        class Field(Optional[str]):<n>            def __repr__( self ):<n>                return f"{self!r}"<n>            def __str__( self ):<n>               return '0' if self is None else str(self.value)<n>            def __eq__(self, other: 'Field'):<n>                if other is None:<n>                    return True<n>                return self.value == other.value <n>```<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. To analyze the test results, use terminal application<n>2. You need to open the test files and copy the test results into the terminal<n><n>### Example<n><n>```shell<n>$ cat question_file.txt<n>Question with Answers<n><n>$ python3 unit test files.py <n>==============================<n><n>Passed (100%)<n>==============================    <n><n>$ <n>```<n><n>## License<n><n>MIT &copy;2021 by [Darshana Nangala](https://github.com/darcunangala)<n>

Or, to be formal, "I am seeking a job." Here's an example:<n><n>```<n>"I'm seeking employment."<n>```<n><n>* We can use the same construction to talk about job-seeking situations as a whole:<n><n>```<n>We are seeking employment.<n>```<n><n>We can also talk about seeking a job generally:<n><n>```<n>I'm looking for a job.<n>```<n><n>Of course, if you have multiple offers, you can say "I am seeking employeemnt with "COMPANY, INC."<n><n>### Input:"Hi Jack, I have an interview tomorrow. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:If you're known to buy presents for others often you would be called what? Choices:  A: go shopping B: generous C: earn money D: have money E: gift buyer<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>**Hint:** <n>"If you're known..." means I, you, or we can also be used here. It also means that you need to select only one word from the choices.<n>**Hint:** A word is a single item in a list or a selection from a group of items<n><n>If I have something and that something has something, but the something doesn't have something else, do I have something? Do I have something? The answer is "yes". Example: I have a car but my car doesn't have a tire.<n><n>### Input:'Pick' is an example of what part of speech?<n><n>### Response:'Pick' is a verb.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>The word pick is the subject of the sentence. A subject is the person, animal, place, thing, idea expressed in a sentence by a noun or a pronoun (the name of a person, animal, place thing or idea. A verb is a (action) word that shows doing. All verbs have action in common.<n>

Choices:    A: The only way to show the prime factorization of an integer is to write its prime factors.  B: Any one factor can be used more than once in a prime factorization. D:The prime factorization of an negative integer must contain prime numbers<n><n>### Response : A or D<n> - A: The only way we can show a number in the prime factorization is writing prime factors<n> - B: Any one factor (prime number) can be used many many times in a prime factorization<n> - C: A prime number is necessary to have the prime factorization of a positive integer. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. Choices:  A: appear suddenly B: bottom out C: go downtown D: scream E: roll over<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the question.<n><n>## Instructions<n>Write a program that is capable of:<n>*   Reading the number of cans and newspapers recycled<n>*   Computing the number of units you would earn for each material<n>*   Computing an amount of money for each material<n>*    Sorting and outputing amounts of money for each material in order of most earned units.<n><n>## Description<n><n>There are two values "count" and "sum" for each of the two materials. "sum" represents the amount of money earned for recycling the units indicated by "count". A "count" is a measure of how many units of each kind of material have been recycled. A "sum" is the amount of money earned if those materials were recycled.<n><n><n>## Code Samples<n>```<n>static void Main(string[] args)<n>{<n>	Console.WriteLine("Enter the number of cans: ");<n>	int count=0;<n>	int sum=0;<n>	while(scanf("%d\n", &count)!=EOF)<n>	{<n>		sum+=(int)("$0.50")<n>			  .Substring(count,1);<n>	}<n>	console.writeline(string.Join(",", Enumerable.Repeat("$", count)));<n><n><n>	Console.WriteLine(string.Join("\n", Enumerable.Range(0, 144, 2).Select<int, string>(x=> $"Enter number of jars of jam you made:\n{x}")));<n><n>	while (scanf("%d\t%d\n", &sum, &count)!= EOF)<n>	{	<n>	}<n><n>	Console.Write(count);<n>		//Console.Write(sum);<n>};<n>```<n><n>## Comments<n><n>## Feedback<n><n>Please check out this page for additional resources:<n>https://mattwelden.github.io/<n><n>## Disclaimer<n><n>I am not a licensed engineer. My code needs some optimization and probably errors. Any advice is greatly appreciated.<n>

Choices:  A: ungulate B: bomber C: body armor D: tank E: hat<n><n>### Response:		<n>We have to know a bit of the syntax too! We're also going to use the return keyword.<n>```<n>function cannonKeepsItOut(armorType) {<n> switch(armorType)<n>    {<n>    case "ungulate":<n>        return "you are protected!"<n>        break;<n>    case "bomber":<n>        return "the bomber jacket will protect you from the cannon ball!"<n>        break; <n>    case "body armor":<n>        return "your body armor should protect you!"<n>        break;    <n>    case "tank":<n>        return "in your tank, you'll be safe from the cannon!"<n>        break;   <n>    case "hat":<n>        return "a hat can't protect you"<n>        break;<n>  default:<n>    return "bad choice!"<n>    break;<n>   }<n>}<n>```<n>### Input: Which one better than the other<n><n>An apple fell on Mr. Black's head. You then add another apple making it 1/2 a bar. You eat one of the apples. How much left do you have?<n><n>### Input A (1 apple)<n><n>### Response A<n><n>```<n>1 apple + 1 apple = 2 apples<n>2 apples ÷ (1/2 a bar) = 4 bars<n>Eat 1 apple = 3 apples<n>3 apples ÷ (¾ a bar) = 5 bars<n>4 bars ÷ (3/5 a bar) = 3 bars<n>3 apples<n>```<n><n>## Instructions: Answer each question. They have soup, bread, and water, which contains no sand. How many scouts are there? Choices A: six, because there are 12 scouts and soup is a sand? B: twelve, because there are 4 bowls of water and water? C: three, because there are 6 scouts, soup, and 7 bowls of water? D: one, because there is 12 scouts, bread, and soup? E: none, because there are 2 scouts, 4 bowls of soup, and bread?<n><n>### Response to Question: F<n><n>#### Reasoning:<n>Because water is contained in the soup no matter how many bowls you have, there are at most 12 scouts<n><n>### Input and Response to Question:<n>D: none, because there is 2 scouts, soup, an bread.<n><n>### Reasoning:<n>You answered incorrectly. If there are 2 scouters, soup, and bread, there must be one more, for a total of 3 scouters.<n><n>The soup could be sand, the bread could be sand, and the water could be sand.<n><n>### Input, and response to Question:<n>Choice E: There are no scouts, because the water contains no sand<n><n>### Reasons:<n>Soup can contain sand, bread can contain sand, and bread<n>

The question itself is on the following line(s). At the end of each question is a question mark. The input is formatted such that the question is on the same line as the command.<n><n>Each command may be one of the following: "ask question", "select name from names", "choose name from names", "find price", "decide between", "decide", "choose", "accept price", and "print list of names and prices".<n><n>The following instructions describe commands. The input for each question in your program is listed in Example 1 through Example 7.<n><n>#### Commands:<n>* ask question: The user will be prompted for an answer.<n>* select: The user will be asked to choose from a list of items.<n>* choose: The user will be given a choice of three items.<n>* decide: The user will be presented with two choices and must choose one.<n>* choose price: The user will be shown prices for one item.<n>* print list: The user will be displayed a list of items and will select one.<n><n>#### Questions:<n>* ask question, "What name sounds cooler?"<n>	* select name from "Dwayne, Larry, Tim", "Larry, Dwayne, Tim"<n>	* choose name from "Dwayee, Larry, Tim"<n>		* choose price, "Dwayne"<n>			* accept price, "$2.00"<n>* ask question, What state south of Kentucky and North of Alabama will you find in people playing the fiddle?"<n>	* choose, "alabama, tennessee, violin case, music store"<n>* ask question: "What's a better word for the person who is in charge of the music?"<n>	* choose name, "music manager, music director, violinist"<n>	* choose price, music manager<n>		* accept price $30,000<n>* ask question

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Bob thought that his Pokemon cards were common and worthless, but he was wrong about them. They were really what? Choices:  A: personal B: special C: shiny D: rare E: irregular<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>Input: What is the correct way to spell the word ‘antidisestablishmentarianism’<n><n>Answer: <n><n>1.antidisestablibalmentarianism<n>2.antidisestablemenarianism<n>3.antidisestablimentarianism<n>4.antidisestabilmentarianism<n>5.antidisestblabmentarianism<n><n>#### Detailed Solution 1:(7 points)<n><n>1.ant. + 11.  dis. Est. 14.  ment. + 18.  arianism<n>a. 7 + 11 + 14 + 18 = 48 points<n>b. antidisestablibality = 1+6+18 = 25 = antidisestablishmetarianism<n>##### Input:Bob thought his Pokemon cards were worthless, but he got more than he expected at the auction. Choices:  A.  $1,000 B.  $1,300 C: $1,001 D. $1,330<n><n>##### Response:B<n>##### Detailed Solution 1: (5 points)<n><n>```python<n>my_list = list(input().split(""))<n>total = 0<n>sum_list = []<n>for i in range (11): #1:11. (123456789 )<n>    for j in range(15): # (11: 21: 120)(21:231: 121 etc..)<n>        #21x5 = 105 <n>        #231x5 = 955<n>        sum_list.append(i+j)<n>i=0<n>for sum_sum in sum_list:<n>    total = total+sum_sum<n>print( "Answer:", total)<n>```<n><n>##### Demonstration<n><n><n>Input: In 1976, Paul Simon recorded the album ‘Still Crazy After All These Years’. 12 years passed before Simon released another solo album. How long ago was it when Paul Simon last made a solo album?<n><n>Answer: 1988<n>```python<n>mylist

Choices:  A: asia B: southern hemisphere C: planet D: east E: earth<n><n>### Response:		<n>The Indian Ocean is a deep, triangular body of water. It is located in the southern hemisphere of the world. The Indian Ocean is bordered by the Red Sea, the African coastline, the Arabian Peninsula, the Persian Gulf, the coastline of the Indian subcontinent, southeast Asia, and the islands in the Malay archipelago. The Indian Ocean is roughly rectangular, measuring about 1,800 miles (south to north) and 1,100 miles (east to west).<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice questions.<n><n>### Input :<n>The total population of a certain country is 100 million people in 2002. The alphabet was created at an unknown point long ago. The list may contain strings which do not exist in any known alphabet since its invention.<n><n>### Solution<n><n><n>```python<n>def create_alphabet(list):<n>  alphabet = " ".join([lower_form for i in range(len(list)+1)])<n>  return alphabet<n><n>def determine_letter_creation_order(history, alphabet, lower_form, history_length):<n>  list_size = len(history

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where would you find people gathered near liquid in a workplace? Choices:  A: water cooler B: opera C: hospital D: hockey game E: beach<n><n>### Response:		<n>C. Where would you find people gathered around liquid at a workplace? Answers: 1: B, 2: D, 3: C, 4: E, 5: A, 6: A, 7: C, 8: A, 9: A, 10: B, 11: A<n><n># Solution Code<n>```javascript<n>//A. For every 12 recycled cans, you receive $0,50 and for every 5 recycled kilos of newpsapers, you receive $ 1,50.<n>console.log('A. For every 5 kilogue of newpsapers, $ 1,5 is paid for every 12 reculed canes, $ 0,50 is received.\n'<n>    + 'A)'+ (B - C) + '\n'<n>    + '\n' + (D - (B-C)) + '\n' )<n><n>//B<n>var BettyPicked = 16<n>var MatthewPicked = ( BettyPicked + 20 ) - 16<n>var NataliaPicked = ( MatthewPicked * 2 ) - 16 <n>var Jar = 7 //Number of jar it takes to complete a jar of jam and number of picks from all of them<n><n>console.log ('B. Betty picked 16 Strawberries, Matt picked'+ MatthewPicked +'more than Betty and twice as the Natalie'<n>            + 'Picked. They Used the Strawberries for the jams. One jar of jam would have'+ Jar<n>            +' Strawberries' )<n>var SalePrice = 4<n>var QuantityFromBetty = 4 * Jar<n>var QuantittyFromMatthew = ( BettyPicked * 2) * 4<n>var QuantitidyFromNatalia = ( MatthewPicked ) * 4<n><n>console.log('Total From Betty:'+ QuantityFromBettty +'x'+ SalePrice +' ='+ ( QuantityFromBetoty * SalePrice) )<n>console.log('Totall From Matthew:'+ MattPicked * 2 * 4 +'x'+ 4 +'  ='+ ( Mat
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where could you find a fox hunting when not in a forest? Choices:  A: open meadow B: arctic tundra C: beach D: great outdoors E: england<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>If foxes hunt for food, I imagine where a fox would find something to hunt when not in a forest, being a fox would have more of an impact on a fox's location than an a forest. In addition, hunting is probably a year round activity, so where they would hunt also needs to be year round, not just in the forest.<n><n>I see these as the four possible locations:<n><n>* Arctic Tundra<n>* Great Outdoors<n>* In a Forest<n>* Open Meadow<n><n>I will show my reasoning in detail why I believe each one of these is incorrect.<n><n>I think that arctic tundra is a very unlikely place to be able to find and hunt for food. Foxes are probably used to living in the warmth and it would be out of their comfort zone for hunting.<n><n>I think the great outdoors is probably not a good location either, since what hunts there? The great outdoors encompases a lot, but hunting is not among a long list of things you could be doing with your time. I can't imagine a fox running around some land, for some reason. It may work if the great outdoors includes the ocean, or a body of water that has fish. But it has to be the ocean, not just a lake, river, creek, etc.<n><n>I think of a forest to mean that it's a wooded area, but I think that's probably too small of an area and too limited. A forest doesn't have to be a huge area, but it likely has trees and a large enough open space to run around freely. I don't believe the open meadow is the correct choice either.<n><n>I imagine the beach is another possible location for a fox to be able to find something to hunt. This is the last location we haven't looked at. Maybe you can go diving for food in the ocean? Diving a lake, river, or creek would not be helpful, though.<n><n>![](/img/fox-hunting-in-the-arctic-tundra.jpg)<n><n>I could not find any image of a fox in an open, clearing. But if you look closely at this image, you can see that there is no bushes, etc. to make a place to hide from a potential
