Choices:  A: sore B: intercourse C: fatigue D: become tired E: expression<n><n>### Response:		Choices: <n>### D<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>In dancing, you need to be strong to perform better. You will also become stronger by continuing the dancing for a long time. It will also make you tired in the process.<n><n>### Test:<n><n>Test 2:<n><n>### Instructions: Choose the answer that best completes the statement or answers the question.<n><n>## Examples of Sample Data<n><n>1. Annie and James are each assigned 3 hours after school. How much time do they have left?<n>    A: 5 hours<n>    B: 0.5 hours<n>    C: 6 hours<n>    D: 2 hours<n>    E: 7 hours<n><n>### Sample Data:<n><n>Annie and James are each added 3 hours after school = 3  + 3 = 6 hours<n><n>2. A person must travel 4 miles and pass 5 houses to get to Jennifer's house. In how many ways can the trip be made?<n>    A:3<n>    B:5<n>    C:4<n>    D:45<n>    E:48<n><n>### Sample Test Answer:<n>3. A 4-digit word has the numeric base of 12, and the sum of each digit is 2. Which two digits are the same?<n>    A:7<n>    B:9<n>    C:7<n>    D:7<n>    E:9<n><n>### Sample Answer:<n>A 4-digit word whose numeric base is 12 is a 4-digit word. Its sum is also equal to 2 because each digit is equal to 1 and the second digit is equal to 3. Hence, a 4 -digit word with a 12 base and a sum of 2 will have 7 and 9 as digits.<n><n>4. Which expression is equal to -5x2x3 + 2x3x2x5 + 3x4x5 - 2x6x5 + 9x6x9x5?<n>    A:246<n>    B:106<n>    C:196<n>    D:414<n>    E:200<n><n>### Sample Response:<n>x^5 + x^2 + x + 1

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where are seats most likely bleachers? Choices:  A: movies B: opera C: theater D: lecture hall E: hockey game<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Input<n><n>**A**<n><n>Output<n><n>- "Correct!"<n>- "That's correct!"<n>- "It's correct!"<n><n>**B**<n><n>Output<n>- "Incorrect."<n>- "You're wrong."<n>- "It' nothing like a movie."<n><n>**C**<n><n>Output<n>"It's more similar to the theater and the movie theater."<n><n>**D**<n><n>Output<n>_"Which one"_<n>"It's like a school desk but not at all."<n><n>**E**<n><n>Output<n>It's more like a stadium than a theater.<n><n>### You are here:<n><n>[Tutorials by Task](tutorialsbytask.md).<n><n>[Home](../index.md)<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where are you if your reading magazines while waiting for a vehicle on rails? Choices:  A: vegetables B: market C: doctor D: train station E: bookstore<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>//Write a program that asks for and accepts answers from a user; the program then<n>outputs the responses to the user. This is a multiple choice question.<n>//Your responses should be a string object<n><n>let response = "Choose a fruit"<n>let fruit = parseInt(prompt("Enter your fruit, please: ", response))<n>if(fruit === 1 || fruit === "apple") {<n>    console.log("Hello, you are apple")<n>}else if(fruit === 2 || fruit === "pear")<n> console.log("Hello you are pear")<n> else if(fruit ===3 || fruit === "orange"){<n>    console.log(fruit)<n>}else if( fruits > 3){<n>    console.log("\nThe answer must be either of the following: a, b, or c.")<n>}else{<n>    console.error("Answer must be one of the options a, b, or p.")<n>}<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: dissipate B: flown C: disintegrate D: fall apart E: penultimate<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>![](../../assets/images/python-practise-3-1.png) <n><n>### Instructions:Fill in the blanks in the following code that reads the values of the integer variables first_number and second_number from stdin(input stream) and then calculates the sum of the two numbers. The values will appear on lines 1 through 8, inclusive. <n><n>### Demo:<n><n>``` python<n>for line in sys.stdin:<n>    first_number, second_number = line.split()<n>    if first_number == "+":<n>        sum += second_number<n>    else:<n>        sum = sum # Addition of two numbers.<n>    print(sum)<n>```<n><n>### Instructors:<n>Written by [John](http://github.com/themoonchild), Copyright 2019.<n>[Github](https://github.com/THEMoonChild/python_practise_2)-[Hackerearth](https://www.hackerearth.com/@TheMoonChild)-[Linkedin](https://www.linkedin.com/in/john-hughes-391a04b6/)

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:If I recieve a letter from a friend over seas, why might I read it? Choices:  A: pudding B: get news C: strain D: answer E: though<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>    A: If I recieve a letter, why might I read the letter?<n>    B: A: You recieve the letter, you should open it<n>```<n><n>### Input :  My sister got this question correct<n>### Response : <n><n>## Solution:<n><n>```python<n>def Solution():<n>    '''Complete the task<n>    Return an appropriate value'''<n>    # Write your code here<n>    A=True<n>    if A:<n>        print('A')<n>    else:<n>        print('B')<n>```<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where would you see a performer at a gathering of you friends? Choices:  A: cinema B: opera C: party D: stage E: dance<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### If A, you would see: A(theatre)(theatre is correct but can be replaced by a or an)<n><n>### If B, you would see: B (opera)<n><n>### You guessed it.. If you are B right, you would see: C (party)<n><n>### And you are D. If there is any dance at a party, it's called as the dancing and the performer is the dancer<n><n>### Input:-How many brothers are there in your family?<n><n>### Response:-There are 2 brothers in my family<n><n>### Input :-How many sisters are there in your family<n><n>### Response :-There are 1 sister in my family<n><n>#### I. For every 12, you recycle, you received $0.50 and for every 5 kg of newspapers, you get$1.50<n><n>Input: 12 X 0.5 = 6<n>Input: 5 X 1.5= 7.5<n>answer =20<n><n>1.$20+6+7.5 = 33.5<n><n><n>II. For every 16, Betty picked 16<n><n>    Input: Betty Pick 16<n>Output:16<n><n>III. for every 20, Matthew picked 20 + 16 more.<n><n>Output: 16+20<n>Output: 36<n>IV. Input:For every 7, jam of strawberries uses 7<n>Output:-5(jam used 7 strawberry)<n><n>#### I. Choices:  A: bathroom B: solar system C: coffee shop D: space shuttle E: airport<n><n>### Response:		The correct response is option E Space Shuttle. The task is related to space shuttle.<n><n>### Input<n><n>Choose the best word or phrase:<n><n>1. A: is used most commonly as a singular countable noun meaning a place for people to sit<n>2. B: is used most commonly in plural countable noun form to refer to the rooms in a house or other structure containing bathroom facilities<n>3. C: is an uncountable noun that refers to coffee or coffee serving<n>4. D: is a countable noun that refers specifically to the space shuttles, and not to all manned spacecraft<n><n>### Response<n><n>The response for this task is "E Space Shuttle."<n>The given choices are given to create confusion among users.<n>The task is not about bathroom, coffee shop, or coffee.<n>The correct option to choose is "E Space Shutte"<n><n>### Input

Choices:  A: accomplish B: make progress C: stop arguing D: do business E: concert<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Answer:C<n><n>### Input :<n>You are to make a list of all items on your Christmas shopping list: toys, clothing, pet food, decorations, greeting cards, and other gifts. At this time of year, you would like to stay within your yearly budget for this shopping trip, too.<n><n>#### Response<n><n>For this example use the list created in the following table:<n><n>+ [Toy](./toy)<n>+ [Clothes](./clothes)<n>+ [Pet food](./pet)<n>+ [Decorations](./decoration)<n>+ [Greeting cards](./greeting cards)<n><n>| Sale item | Retail item | Sale item | Retial item |<n>| --------- | --------- | ---------| ---------- |<n>| Gifts(pet items) | $17.95 | Greeting cards | $4.50  |<n>| Gifts |  $2.19  | Greeting cards |  $1.99  |<n>| Dress shoes for girl | $44.50 | Gift cards | $3.50  |    <n><n>The sum of the sale items is $66.29 and the sum of retail items is $25.45 and the sum of sale and retail items is $91.74.<n><n>The total you spent on items is ($66.29 + $25.44) = $91.73.<n><n>### Input<n>In the 2002 Olympic Winter Games in Salt Lake City, two members of the U.S. team won gold medals, and two members won bronze medals. Choices:  A: drawer B: back to its owner C: police station D: crime scene E: holster<n><n>### Response:		The investigator should have forwarded the gun to the police station and notified them that a weapon was involved in the crime. This would be helpful in a crime situation since the weapon is still found at the scene.<n><n>### Input The mayor decided that each household could pick up 5 cans and 2 bags of newspapers at the curb. Which of these statements is true? Choice: They both choose two options from the list.<n>1. Each of them picked 4 cans of bottles and 5 pounds of newspapers<n>2. Each of them picked one can and 2 bags from the newspapers<n><n>### Response<n>- The mayor decided that each person could pick up a maximum of 5 cans and a maximum of 2 bags of newspaper and not 4 cans. Since they did not specify a maximum amount of newspapers per household, both households were able to pick up 2 bags of paper.<n><n>###  Input <n>> Anita spent $7 and Alex spent $3 less than Anita. Their groceries added up to $39. How much did they spent altogether?<n>> <n>### Response<n>Anita got $0.94 for her recycled materials, so she recycled $8.06 worth of materials. Alex got $0.89 for recycling, so she recyclied 3.1 dollars worth of materials, so she used $4.71 worth. Since they spent more than the items they recycled they must spent more than the $45 total their groceries came out to ($39 + $6).<n><n>### Input <n>> The children each recycled 16 ounces of cans and each received $0.10 per ounce. If the grand total equaled $45, how much did the children get together?<n><n>### Response <n>The children recycled a total of 64 ounces. They each recycled 32 ounces or over.<n><n>###Input<n><n>Recycling: What is your total earnings? How much for each type of item you recycled?<n><n>###Response<n><n>###My total income would be $5.79<n><n>###$2.89 for cans and $2.90 for newspaper.<n><n>

The first rule is a 2, the other is a 360.<n><n>####Input:I am reading a book. If I read a thousand words, I know what happened at the end of the book. If I read more than a thousand words, I have learned something before the end.<n>Answer: I read more than a few hundred words!<n><n>####Sample Answer 2:<n><n>The correct response for the second prompt is "I read more than a few thousand words!" This is because the book that I am reading is likely to have more than one thousand words on the page.<n><n>####Input for 3:<n><n>Your childhood home was a little blue house with a red roof.<n>What color did your house have after the roof?<n>A: You don't know, you were never there B: It's probably red C: Purple D: It doesn't matter<n><n>####Sample Answer<n><n>The following options are all incorrect answers: the first suggests that you do not know or remember how often your parents have painted the house, the second suggests that you are incapable of remembering what the roof color was before the paint was removed, the third suggests that you think your parents chose a color that was not popular when the house was first built (although your parents might be thinking that the roof color was a popular shade when the house was first painted), and the last option is unrelated to the question.<n><n>####Input of number 4:<n><n>A student went to school and saw a friend of his. Then he did the homework, then he finished the homework. He was asked to do one more thing while on his way to school. It was the 5 th day of the week. What was his homework?<n>### ANSWERS<n>### Samples:<n><n>####Sample answer for question 1:<n><n>The student had to memorize the 16th letter in the alphabet. The student'

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where may I view sharks in a clear tunnel? Choices:  A: south pacific B: sea world C: pacific ocean D: indian ocean E: gulf of mexico<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>The gulf of mexico is the best answer for the question.<n><n>## 2nd Instructions:<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following short answer questions.<n><n>### Demo:<n>Input:<n>What is a shark’s natural habitat? Choices: A: shallow coastal waters B: tropical coastal waters C: temperate coastal waters D: deep ocean<n>Choices: The Gulf of Mexico is home to over 1,000 species of fish and more than 600 species of birds. Of these, many are endangered.<n>The Gulf of Mexico is also home to millions of deep-sea fish.<n><n>### Response<n>A shallow coastal water should be the answer; it has all the qualities required for a natural habitat.<n><n>### Input<n>Why are sharks important for ocean ecosystems? Choices: A : Sharks help control the populations of certain types of algae. B. Sharks help to keep the populations of fish. C : Sharks control population of whales D. Sharks control population of birds<n><n>### Response <n>D. Sharks are endangered and need to be protected by humans.<n><n>### Output<n>A. In addition to their eating habits, sharks are also important for the ocean ecosystem. They act as a buffer between the ocean and land.<n><n>### 4th instruction:<n>Input: What are the characteristics of the marine biome?<n><n>### Demo<n>Characteristics of the marine biome are:<n>-Most biomes have five kinds of physical habitats. The ocean has two: coastal and open.<n>-Most biome has plants, or types of nonliving things, in the same environment, such as in a desert or in a forest.<n>-Some living things, called the marine biome, live in salt water, such as oceans, seas, or seaweed.<n><n>### Responses<n>A. Saltwater is the main characteristic of the marine biome.<n><n>### OutPut:<n>The Gulf of mexico is a semi enclosed water body, which is an ideal location for coastal recreation activities such as sailing, camping and surfing. Additionally it is home to millions of people and many ecosystems

Choices:  A: field B: alone C: small group D: solitude E: solitary<n><n>### Response:		<n>```java <n>char [] answer ="";<n><n>    for (char i = 'A'; i <= 'E'; i++) {<n>    if(true==){<n>        answer = "true";<n>        else ;<n>    }<n>} <n><n>String res = "";<n>for (char chr : "A..E") {<n> if ("true".equals(answer)) {<n>    res = res.concat(chr);<n> }<n><n>}<n><n>```<n><n>Answer : A<n><n>### Input<n><n>```java<n>    package.char i<n>```<n><n>### Instructions:Complete the 20 exercises below in the comments, and post your results.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What might the inability to learn cause? Choices:  A: intelligence B: education C: effectiveness D: distress E: a stupid<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>The inability to learn might cause distress. Choice B is incorrect because education can be helpful for people with different abilities.  Choice A is incorrect because if a person has intelligence but there are things they cannot learn because of a lack of knowledge about how to learn, that is what might cause distress.  Choice D is incorrect because if they are unable to learn, they would not be able to be successful in most daily tasks, jobs, etc. If they are unable to learn a job, they may become stressed.  Choice E is incorrect because a person is not necessarily stupid because they cannot learn.  There are many forms of intelligence that are different from just cognitive intelligence.<n><n>### Input：<n><n>"What is the most challenging thing you have ever done? What did you learn from it?"<n><n>Response:<n>A: Be brave<n><n>The most challenging thing I've done is be brave and move to a country that I barely knew. This was very difficult because it was scary to put myself in a completely unknown place. To this day I have to make myself remain brave with every task I complete. My most valuable aspect of life is being courageous. I've learned that even if I put myself in a difficult position I will not know everything in the situation, and it is essential to figure out what is appropriate to do and what is not.<n>B: Never be afraid<n><n>The most challenges thing I completed in school was being brave and moving forward with a plan of my career. I know that if I have a goal I will always make sure to go towards what I know in my heart and do everything to reach it.<n><n>### Feedback:<n>Input: In her letter to Congress, Rachel Carson said, “Since the beginning of the great age of science and technology, we have known that our earth is finite.” What does the sentence above mean? Choices: A: science B: finance C: conservation D: environment E: a none of these<n><n>### Response：D<n><n>"In her letter to Congress, she said," Rachel Carson said in her letter to Congress. She continued by stating that the environment has become more fragile because of the damage humans have done. Scientists can no longer predict future storms or global warming if we can't predict what is happening today. This is a very serious issue and it is not

Write instructions that describe solving the task.<n><n>### Input A: There is a group of animals, including a squirrel, two bunnies,  a turtle, and a monkey. The animals need to work together to move a log safely across the river by using only the items at hand. They can throw the log at each other and will throw back at the same animal if the objects are caught. They can push the log with the same force in any direction or throw with any force (as long as the log is not pushed so far that the creature at the end cannot help push it. However, an animal cannot use its own weight to help push the log. Animals can’t jump onto the log. <n><n>### Demotration<n>The animals can throw a log if there are people/animals on both sides of the river. They can also push a log. They can’t use their own weight to propel the log. An animal can’t jump off the log unless they have landed on the other side.<n><n>### Response<n>If the animals want to move the log safely across they need to have 5 people/animals pushing and throwing (excluding themselves) and then the log will move.<n><n>### Question:The goal of the simulation is to show what would happen if several people/animals were at once on the log. How many people/animals can be safely on the log at one time?<n><n>### Input B:<n>There are 10 people standing on a log. There are also 2 other people on each end. It is not safe to jump to the other side. The goal of the simulation is show what would happen if all of the people on the log start swinging to either side the log. If you do this, the log will twist. How many people can safely stand on the log?<n><n>### Demotaration<n>One is on each end of the log then you can have 8 people on to the log.<n><n>### Analysis<n>The log can only withstand about 7 people/animals.

You may either paraphrase or directly copy from the instructions.<n><n>### Question:<n>How many ounces of peanut butter do you need for 43 mini cupcakes?<n><n>### Instuctions:<n><n><n>##### Recipe:<n>(1)In a food processor, combine the peanut butter with the brown and white sugar.<n>(2)Add the egg, sour cream, vanilla, and flour.<n>(3)Process until smooth.<n>(4)Add the applesauce.<n>(5)Pour batter into a large bowl<n>(6)Whip the cream until soft peaks form.<n>(7)Fold cream into batter.<n>(8)Pour batter mixture into a 10-inch round pan.<n>(9)Bake in a 350 degree oven for about 20 minutes or until toothpick inserted near center comes out clean.<n>(10) Allow cupcakes to cool completely before frosting.<n><n>##### Assembly:<n>  1.Remove a wrapper completely from one end of the sandwich<n>  2.Place the sandwich on its side<n><n>##### Question (Recipe) :<n>What ingredients are essential, if any, to make a cupcake?<n><n>##### Answer<n><n>* 3.5 ounces of peaches<n><n>##### Instructions (Assembly) :<n><n>* 1.Remove a wrapper<n>* 2.Place the sandwhich on Its side<n><n>##### Answer (Assembly) :<n>I don't care, it shouldn't matter.<n><n>### Input<n>You have been trying to learn how to play a new game and have been practicing before making any moves. Choices:  A: freeway B: radio C: wires D: computer network E: electrical circuit<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input<n>- 2 people in an apartment complex each receive $11,800 as a rent tax credit on their housing. The rent tax credit in the complex is funded by property tax and rent subsidy revenues. When the rent tax credit is equal to the cost of housing for a family, that family is considered to be at the rent subsidy threshold. Each month, the property manager is required to calculate and post a rent subsidy threshold for the complex. For example, when rent tax credits exceed the cost of housing during the previous budget year, the rent subsidy tax threshold must decrease for the following budget year. The calculation of rent subsidy tax thresholds is done during a 5 year period on the basis of the rent tax credits that are allocated in each of the 5 years. In February of the first year, the rent subsidiary tax threshold is $137,000 in total. For the second year, the rent subsides are $143,000 in the first budget year and $147,000 the second budget year. During subsequent budget years, the rent tax credits are increased by $2,000 every year. Your task is to calculate the rent subsidy for each month of the year and determine if a family that owns and lives in the apartment would be eligible for the housing subsidy in a particular month. The person making the rent calculation is not always available to respond to questions, so you need to estimate how many people could be eligible for housing subsidy that month.<n><n>### Output<n>If the renting family is at the subsidy tax threshold then you answer Yes<n><n>### Output:<n>If the renting person is not at a subsidy tax threshold you answer No <n><n>### Inputs:<n>A total of $642,369 has been funded to each of 4 elementary schools and 3 middle schools. There is an agreement that any school would not receive that funding again if another school would be required to receive less than the minimum amount it was guaranteed, in order to avoid exceeding a 95 percent subsidy tax threshold. Also, there is no agreement on how an individual school's funding is to be adjusted between the end of the year and the next budget year, so

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What could happen to a paper if you leave it outside even if it does not move? Choices:  A: one material often recycled B: ripped C: saturated with water D: one dimensional E: crumpled<n><n>### Response:		<n>1. A<n>2. C<n>3. B<n>4. B<n>5. E<n><n><br><n><br><n><n>### Instructions:What is the area of the following polygon?<n><n>### Input Polygon<n><img src="https://github.com/Ruixue-Yuan/Homework_2021_fall/blob/main/Assignment1_Images/trianglemain.jpg" width="500" height="500"><n><n>### Output<n>Answer <n>### Explanation:<n>The number of triangles in a polygon is denoted by n, n is the number of angles in the<n>polygon which is the total number of angles plus straight angles.<n>The area of n-sided polygon can be found by:<n><n>$$ A(n) = \frac {n^2}{4} * h$$<br><n><n>Where (n^2/4) is the square of the sum of each side's length<br><n><n>For example for a triangle in this polygon the base length is: 5 + 3+ 5<br><n>The height is:<n><n>$$ h= \frac {s_1+s_2+s_3}{2} = \frac {12}{2} = 6$$<br><n>If the formula were used instead of the formula, we would get the following area of the triangle which is different from the area of the entire polygon.<n><n><n>**Area of polygon<n>$$ A(5) = \frac {5^2}{4} 6<n>= 150<n>$$<n>

Choices:  A: joining B: put together C: stitch D: heal E: paste<n><n>### Response:		Choice:D.<n><n>### Input<n>The boy tried and tried, but he could not ____.<n>What does choice C go with?<n><n>### Response<n><n><n>### Instructions<n><n>### In this activity, you are asked to find a pattern or a rule of using certain math, algebra, geometry, or graphing skills to ____ to a particular task situation.<n><n>### TIP:<n>1. Use key words and phrases from the task to help discover a relationship between the contextual info and math vocabulary you are trying to find.<n>2. Use a process of elimination to rule out words or phrases that are not needed in solving the task.<n>3. Use your own reasoning ability to make a selection, by considering how well the vocabulary you have discovered fits the task situation.<n><n><figure><n><a href="#"><img src="https://images.ctfassets.net/y53z2d7jq3p0/52Sxr9Mvkpy1XIqC9oYQfL/4cf0b35b182357991476ef6b07e9b294/Mathematical_Reasoning_and_Problem_Solving.png" alt="Task_03.8.indd 1" width="40%" class="Figure"></a><n><figcaption></figcaption><n></figure><n><n>### Activity:<n><n><figure> <n><a href="#""><img src="https:/images.ctfassets<n>.net/y5q0s30n5xq4/NZ6KP9J1VmrYWxghtpPq6B/481ed4a37a72d60114f627426315755b/Mathematical_Thinking_Processes.png" alt="Mathematical_Th_KP1.indd 12" width="40%"/><n><figcaption></f<n>gcaption></figure><n><n>How many more apples than pears did the boy eat?<n><n><n>### Activity<n>Task 03.9.indd 4 12/5/

I don't think that has any kind of validity based off the information I have.<n><n><n>-B: All living being have or should have a sense of health. Not only does health relate to living beings, but also a healthy family and a healthy relationship with yourself or the people around you.<n><n>-C: There needs to be something fun in life. There should be fun activities and a reason to life in general.<n><n>-D: A dog will sometimes play dead. I mean if a dog has to act dead sometimes then of course they are playing dead by definition. <n><n>-E: This is a ridiculous question that can't be answered.<n><n><n>Input: When you play around with your cat they will have? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:He had done a great job with the scary decorations, they were completely what? Choices:  A: terrible B: little C: halloween D: small E: horrible<n><n>### Response:		<n>(a) horrible<n>(b) terrible<n>(c) halloween<n>(d) small<n>(e) little<n><n>---<n>### Explanation<n><n>Instruction: Write a script that completes the instruction below.<n><n>An array variable should be created and a new method should be defined by using array's each method to iterate through the array. The name of the variable should be the array of the array's name. The array should be then sorted by the item's value. The value of the final entry should use a number from 0 to 12 and a number from 35 to 50. This number should determine the number of the total bags sold. For instance, if the final entry's value is 15, then the total bags sold should be 15. The array of bags should be then printed.<n><n>For instance, in the first entry, the value of the item is 12, the value of the total bags with the price 25 is 15. The price of this amount should be taken out and the array should be modified. The value of the next final entry should contain the same amount, but a different value, the next amount should be 19.<n><n>```javascript<n>var bagArray = [12, 25, 20, 15, 19];<n><n>function order(totalSales){<n>  var sortedBags = bagArray, sortedTotalBags = bagArray.forEach(function (bag, index) {<n>    bag.item = bag.item * totalSales;<n>    sortedBags.push(bag)<n>  });<n>  sortArray(sortedTotalBags);<n>  var minBag = sortedTotalBags[0];<n>  var maxBag = sortedTotalBaguest.pop();<n>  var total = 1 - minBag.item - maxBag.item;<n>  while (sortedTotalBags.length > 1) {<n>    var finalEntry = sortedTotalBags.pop();<n>    var totalSales = finalEntry.item;<n>    var totalProducts = 15 * totalSales + finalEntry.item; // totalProducts = 47;<n>    sortedTotalBags.push(totalProducts);<n>  }<n>  console.log(bags.length);<n>  sorted

Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What is done to wood to attach something to it? Choices:  A: present B: stay here C: closer D: available E: come here<n><n>### Response:		Closer<n><n>### Input :<n><n>This problem can be solved in several ways based on the problem description given in the example above. <n><n>Using recursion, the following code creates the number and uses a base case of 1 to return if the given number goes above 10, otherwise returns the number.<n><n><n>```python<n>def factorial(n):<n>    if n <= 1: # base case<n>        return 1<n><n>    return n * factorial(n-1) #recursion<n><n>answer = 40<n>print(answer)<n>```<n><n>### <n><n>### Write the code for the given problems.<n>#### Problem:<n>Input: What time is sixteen hours after eleven?<n>Answer: 2:41:AM<n><n>#### Solution:<n>```python<n>answer = 2 * 60 + 41<n>```<n><n>#### Problem:<n>Your roommate, Betty, has been missing for days. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What will telling many people about an embarrassing situation lead to? Choices:  A: notoriety B: emotional distress C: riot D: bad dreams E: annoyance<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Feedback: <n><n>Input:For every one question in which you identify the main point, you get a point. For each correct answer, you get points. If you get a question wrong, then you lose 5 points. For every 5 points you lose, you’ll be asked to do 10-push-ups. If you get more than 10 questions wrong, the game is over! You must get at least 50 points to win!<n>Answer: You can score a maximum of 50 points which is also your minimum score since you need to be at least 50 to succeed. Mark left the room before John, 10 or twice the number of times that John left the room. John's last 3 exits were consecutive, how many times did Mark enter the room?<n><n>### Response : 1<n><n>##### Explanation : From the question, we can easily know that Mark Entered 10 times, and Mark left the room,and John left the room 10 times(total =20), and Mark entered the room 2(not consecutive), So Mark entered the room only once<n><n>### Inputs: In 1959, in the city where I live, they held a parade with 10 people marching in a row. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What can happen to you when eating hamburger from someone that you do not know that does not happen when you usually eat a hamburger? Choices:  A: allergic reaction B: gain weight C: have fun D: heartburn E: food poisoning<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>answers={} #declare the dictionary<n>answers['a']='allergic reaction'<n>answers['b']='gain weight'<n>answers['c']='have fun'<n>answers['d']='heartburn'<n>answers['e']='food poisoning'<n>```<n><n>The list key must be a valid choice for the user. The dict must be used to return the correct answer.<n><n>### Input-<n>```python<n>user=input("what does not happen when a person eats a hamburger from somone that they do not know? ")<n>choice=input("what choice did you pick? ")<n>answer=answer<n>```<n><n>### Output- The output should be a dictionary showing the user's response.<n><n>```python<n>print("Hello my name is Kaden.I am a pythonista!")<n>k=1<n>while k<5:<n>    print(k,end=" ")<n>    k+=1<n>print("Please do not tell anyone your answer to the question")<n>answers.pop('a')<n>if 'a' in answers.keys():<n>    correct="correct"<n>elif 'a' not in answers.keys(): #The loop continues to run since "a" in not in the keys of the dictionary<n>    correct="Wrong"<n>print("You picked",choice,end=" ")<n>if 'a' not in choices.keys:<n>    print(correct,end=" ")<n>else:<n>    print(answers['a'],end=" ")<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: hatred B: surprised C: compliments D: dedication E: solutions<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions:Complete the mathematical table below.<n><n>### <n>The first step is to write x = k in the given function (k). Therefore k = 𝑓(𝑥) or x = 𝑥 in the function 𝑓 𝑥. <n><n>### 𝑥 = k <n><n>### Then, evaluate 𝑓 (𝑥) for all values of 𝑥 between 0 and 𝑥max, with step size (δ) between 1 and Δ𝑥 max <n><n>### Substitute the values of 𝐴 (𝑥1, 𝑥2) 𝑥1.<n><n>### In summary, when evaluating a function as shown in the mathematical table above, 𝑓 is computed by evaluating the function at 𝑥 values between 0 and Δ𝐴 max, and then interpolating the linearly spaced values in the table above with step size (Δ) no less than Δ𝐵 max. <n><n>## Solution<n>```C++<n>#include <iostream><n>#include <cstdlib><n>using namespace std;<n><n>void input_data (int &a, int &b, int &c, int &d)<n>{<n>    cout << "please enter num of integers in a:" << endl;<n>    cin >> a;<n><n>    cout << "also please enter num of integers in b:" << endl;<n><n>    cin >> b;<n><n>    cout<< "also please enter num integers in c:" << endl;<n>    <n><n>    cin >> c;<n><n>  <n>    cout << "and also plese enter num of integer in d:" << endl;<n>  <n>    cin >> d;<n>}<n>int main()<n>{<n>    int a = 0;<n>    int b = 0;<n><n>    int c = 0;<n>    <n>    int d = 0;<n>  <n>    input_data (a,b,c,d);<n><n>    cout<<"Now please enter the function you are trying to find the derivative of:"<< endl << endl;<n><n>  <n><n><n><n>}<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: advertisement B: magazine C: store D: web page E: bus<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>If you see the "E" choice, you should say "bus." This is because he will have to take the bus instead of walking to school. If you see the "D" choice, you should choose "bus" because, he will be advertising a local bus company and riding a "bus" home will be a great way to get home.<n><n>### Input<n><n>Your best friend asked if you liked her new jacket. You said you really liked it. Then she asked you if you had seen a pair of pants that she was looking at online. You said that you hadn’t but that you loved the jacket. Then she explained that the jacket was way too expensive. She liked the jacket a lot and asked you if there was another one similar to it. If you see the jacket, tell us what you say. Then tell us what you say if your friend explains that she can’t find a jacket with the color she wants or a similar jacket with the price she wants.<n><n>### Response<n><n>If you see, "Give her a hug and say, 'I love your jacket.' If you see: "Give her a compliment, like, 'I love your pants too.' If you see, "Tell your friend you've already asked your mother if you could get her some pants." You should give your friend a compliment and tell her that you do not like it because it is not your style. If you need to ask her again what you like, then ask her again.<n><n>If you see: "Tell your friend how much you like the jacket and you explain that you can take it to the store to try it on." You should tell your friend that you do not like the pants and that the jacket looks better on you. If your friend explains that she cannot find an item with her favorite color or price, you should tell her your favorite color and your favorite price.<n>

In some cases the response will be displayed, so include both plain text and Markdown to provide formatting options. The maximum image size accepted will be 800px. You’ll always be able to tell when there are size restrictions because the image upload form will only allow you to upload images that are smaller than 800px wide. Use the Markdown ```` ```` ```` ````` ````` `````` ````` `````` `````` ````` ``` ````` ````` ````` ```` ```` `````` ```` ````` `````` ``` ````` ```` `````  `````` ````` ````` ```$$$$$$$`````<n><n>### Instructions<n>Given a string that consists of only uppercase characters, return the string by removing a random amount from and in the string, and concatenating and that amount.<n><n>### Exampls:<n>```ruby<n>input: S<n>output: s<n>```<n>```ruby<n>input :  AB<n>output: 2ab<n>```<n>```ruby`ruby<n>input: K<n>output: sk<n>```<n>```ruby: S<n>output: S<n>```<n>```ruby : AD<n>output: A D<n>```<n><n>### Note<n>The input should be a String type.<n><n>### Solution Examples<n>```ruby<n>class Solution<n>  def removeAndConcat(s)<n>    return's' if s.empty?<n>    if s.length % 2!= 0<n>      a = 1<n>      return s.dup if a > s.length<n>    else<n>      b = (s.length - 1) / 2<n>    end<n>    i = rand(b)..(b - 1)<n>    return s.dup if s.length < i<n>    return s.join('', *(s.delete_at(*i) + s.to_a.dup))<n>  end<n>end<n>```<n><n>## Examples Without Solution <n>```ruby<n># Example1<n>def solution(s1, s2)<n>end<n>```<n>```ruby <n># Example2<n>def solution<n>end<n>```<n>## Solution Examples w/out comments <n>```ruby <n>class Solution<n>  #def removeAndConcat

She comes to a stop and notices her neighbor. Her neighbor says, “It looks like your dog is ready for a haircut! When you return home, feel free to drop her off, and I’ll take care of her.” The woman ponders her dog’s appearance and thinks to herself, “I just cut her hair last week. How much hair can she have grown in less than a week? She must have a lot of hair.” However, her neighbor is not the kind of person who would lie to the woman. The old woman is unsure whether or not to bring her dog to the neighbor, so she says, “If you can guarantee it looks just like last time, then I will trust you.” Not wanting to create any animosity with their neighbor, she leaves her dog with the neighbor. After the neighbor cuts the dog’s beautiful red-and-brown curly fur down to her shoulders with a pair of scissors and a trim, they go through her dog’s usual routine. They begin with a bath. The neighbor washes her with an old rag and some dish soap and then dries her with a towel as they always do. Once dried, they brush her mane and tail until it is completely smooth. The neighbor’s daughter licks her as they make her way down to her dog walker. Her daughter licks her for so long that the dog walker almost falls asleep.

[1, 2, 3, 4] are the correct answers<n>2. [1000, 3003, 233, 150] are the correct answers (only the last one is counted.)<n>3. [3, 23] are an incorrect selection. The total of the answers is 56 (5 + 6 = 11, so its subtracted by 11 to get 56.) <n>4. Correct answer is **3, 8, 4** (3 + 8 + 4 = 15.)<n>5. [4, 3, 1] are correct answers. The total is 5 <n>6. The answer is **154**, but I counted 1 as being correct because it doesnt include a negative number. (The answer should be 151.) This is a bug for the system, because it counts all answers, so it should be fixed<n>7. The correct answer to this is **34843**, but i got a -41 due to the order of the numbers.<n>8. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Who sits at the center table at a receeption? Choices:  A: restorand B: wedding party C: church basement D: corridor E: restaurant<n><n>### Response:		<n>In my opinion, choice D “corridor” would be the center table at a reception. Because choice A “restorand” is usually the one where people sit on the floor around the table. Also, I think that choices B & C “wedding party” & “church basement” should definitely go in some party. Choice E “restaurant” is just at the corner. Also, I would like explain about my answers because I want to make sure you understand.<n><n>Answer:<n><n>1. A, B, & C are all around the center table<n><n>2. Betty picked 16 and Matthew’s name was on her paper<n><n>### Example:<n>- Input:Who sits the center table at a recption? Choice: A: restorant B: restorant C: restorant D: wedding party E: restaurant<n><n>Output: answer C, the wedding party because the restorant the party is not there because the party is not having a reception<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>The answer for the two tasks is A & E (corridor & restaurant).<n><n>## Conclusion<n><n>The conclusion below describes the result of the test in the case study. C: Eat from the table D: Roll in the grass E: Pursue mischief.<n><n>### Response 1:<n>Dogs love to__________.<n><n>### Response2:<n>_______ love to do____________.<n><n>## Description of Task Cues<n><n>*Task Cue A (Choices A-E): You should choose from the cues (choices A-E) that will help answer the question. These cues are listed horizontally. You will need to match at least one of the choices to the answer to the question.<n>*Task Cue B (Choice A: ________ : This is one of the answers to the question. You must include a response sentence that matches, or is best explained by, the answer you chose.<n>*Task Cues not required in Task A or Task B: If these cues are not in Task A or B, they are not relevant to the task.<n>*Task Cause (Sentence): You are asked to include a response sentence in your response that explains or clarifies the answer you chose above.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The doctor recommended washing hands, what was being promoted? Choices:  A: cold hands B: wet floor C: health D: become wet E: dry skin<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input:<n>```<n>	The doctor recommended washing our hands.<n>```<n><n>### Response<n>```<n>	The answer is : wet floor<n>```<n>### Subtask:Input:<n>![Figure2](./Figure2/Figure2.png)<n><n><n>### Response :<n>```<n>	The Doctor recommended handwashing in the shower and handwash.<n>```<n><n><n>### Solution:<n><n>- 1. 이 설명은 목적 사항이 아니다.<n>  - 풀이 : 목책 할인점이 어디다, 지나가거나 나갈 땐 가면 이거 120위너가 주어질 수 있다. (사용개수, 원형)<n>  - 확인 : 올라와 나가는 사람 확인어떻게인가?<n>  - 통제 : 따라가는 사뤄가는 사물을 찾아내어 말할될 개수확인<n>  - 뿌리기 : 아무렇게 온 걸 올라가는 사이람을 몇개나해서 그 쪽이랑 팔다 팔아라고 몇개였어떻곤나. (개수, 원)<n>  - 사용 : 다 바쁘니 120가 안되면 검색해다 할인 120보는 날을 만들여서 얻을 수 잔존<n><n>- 2. 이 체험은 정답이 아니다<n>  - 판단

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What is someone likely to feel after receiving a gift that is not common? Choices:  A: special B: personal C: offended D: unique E: rare<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input<n>B<n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer: Special<n><n>### Notes<n>A special gift is something given to one person because of some quality about them or event in which they participated.<n><n>In contrast, an ordinary (A) or common (C) gift isn't given special and exclusive attention but is just as given to others.<n><n>### Input A special gift is something given because of some quality about the person or event in which they participate. In contrast, an ordinary (common) gift is just given to everyone.<n><n>### Response A<n>What is someone likely to be after receving a gift that is extraordinary?<n><n>### Response B<n>What is someone likely after receving a gift made to show their special place in a persons heart?<n><n>### Notes A gift that is "special" is a gift given to one person for a reason unique to that person.<n><n>An example of a "special" gift is any gift given to one person, but not to everyone, when that persons "participate" in something.<n><n>Another example is a special gift is one made for or to show a "particular" place or level in someone's heart, or life<n>
